columns.text:
In this exercise, we'll analyze how to determine a company's stock price with changing growth.

Let's get started!

Let's start by explaining what the Constant Growth Model is and how we can use it to calculate the stock price. The Constant Growth Model is a method of assessing stocks. This model assumes that dividends paid by a company will continue to rise through a constant rate of growth for an indefinite period. This method helps investors calculate a stock's current value based on future dividend payments. To calculate the value of a stock, the model takes the infinite sequence of dividends per share and discounts them to the present using the required rate of return. It is based on the mathematical properties of an infinite series of numbers growing at a constant rate: $$\text{P} = \dfrac{D}{r - g}\tag{1}$$ Where: P- the current share price D - the next dividend the company has to pay g - the expected growth rate r - the required rate of return

We are given a bond that does not pay dividends for the first nine years.

Then, it starts paying dividends of $17 ten years from today and dividends will have a constant growth rate of 3.9% every year thereafter.

The required rate of return is 12.5%

Hence, considering that we know the price of the dividend in year ten is \$17, we can find out what was the price of the bond in year nine by using Eq.$(1)$:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{P}_9 &= \dfrac{D_{10}}{r - g} \\[15pt]
&= \dfrac{\$17}{12.5\% - 3.9\%} \\[25pt]
&= \$197.67441
\end{aligned}$$

Now that we have found the price of the stock in year 9, we can calculate the current price by discounting the price in year 9:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{P}_0 &= \dfrac{P_{9}}{(r + 1)^9} \\[15pt]
&= \dfrac{\$197.67441}{(12.5\% + 1)^9} \\[15pt]
&= \$68.48220
\end{aligned}$$

**Let's recap what we have learned in this exercise!** We started by explaining the Constant Growth Model and how we can use it to find the stock price. Then, by using the Constant Growth Model, we calculated the price of bond at year 9. We learned that we could find any price by discounting the future price at the required rate of return. So, we discounted the price at year 9 to find the current price.
